content.body: bakkot: Currently, some preambles give a parameter-'type' as "a List of Foo" (mostly "a List of ECMAScript language values"). But what about if the 'element type' isn't a single type? E.g., in #1713, MakeIndicesArray's _indices_ param is a List where each element is either a Match Record or *undefined*. Should the preamble just say "a List" (as it does currently), or should there be a (standard) way to convey the type of elements?
content.formatted_body: bakkot: Currently, some preambles give a parameter-'type' as "a List of Foo" (mostly "a List of ECMAScript language values"). But what about if the 'element type' isn't a single type? E.g., in #1713, MakeIndicesArray's indices param is a List where each element is either a Match Record or undefined. Should the preamble just say "a List" (as it does currently), or should there be a (standard) way to convey the type of elements?

content.body: would be good to get a standard wording, but everything unambiguous I can think of ends up pretty long
"a List whose elements are each either undefined or a Math Record" is about the best I can do
